entry.title: å†…ç”Ÿè½¬æ¢ Probit æ¨¡å‹
entry.content:
Source:

[1]æé•¿ç”Ÿ,åˆ˜è¥¿å·.åœŸåœ°æµè½¬çš„åˆ›ä¸šæ•ˆåº”â€”â€”åŸºäºå†…ç”Ÿè½¬æ¢Probitæ¨¡å‹çš„å®è¯åˆ†æ[J].ä¸­å›½å†œæ‘ç»æµ,2020(05):96-112.[PDF]

[2]The adoption and impact of E-commerce in rural China: Application of an endogenous switching regression model [PDF]

å†…ç”Ÿè½¬æ¢ Probit æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œè§£å†³æ ·æœ¬è‡ªé€‰æ‹©å¯¼è‡´çš„å†…ç”Ÿæ€§é—®é¢˜ã€‚

The ESR model was developed by Lee (1982) as a generalization of Heckmanâ€™s selection correction approach (Abdulai and Huffman, 2014).

Methods

Although the propensity score matching (PSM) is also used to address the issue of self-selection bias, it has the drawback that it is unable to address selection bias originating from unobserved factors. The ESR model accounts for the self-selection bias and unobservable factors in the estimation by bringing in instrumental variable and counterfactual analysis.

The estimation of the ESR model proceeds in two stages: Probit regression is used in the first stage to determine the probability of land rental. The second-stage regression estimates the de-terminants of outcomes, respectively, for the outcome of renting land or not. Nevertheless, this two-stage approach causes the problem of heteroskedastic residuals, which cannot be used to obtain consistent standards errors without cumbersome adjustments (Lokshin and Sajaia, 2004). Therefore, the full information maximum likelihood estimator is used to overcome the problem through a simultaneous estimation of the two stages involving one selection and two outcome equations (Lokshin and Sajaia, 2004).

First Stage: decesion equation

$T_i^*$ cannot be observed, it can be expressed as a function of observable elements in the latent variable model as below:

  • $T_i= 1$: land rental (in or out), otherwise $T_i = 0$;
  • $Z_i$ : factors that impact land rental

Second Stage: the impact of land rental on entrepreneurship

When $T_i = 1$,

When $T_i = 0$,

  • $T{Ti}^*$ and $T{Ni}^*$: æµè½¬åœŸåœ°å’Œæ²¡æœ‰æµè½¬åœŸåœ°å†œæ°‘çš„åˆ›ä¸šæ¦‚ç‡ï¼›

entry.title: IELTS-Writing-Answer-0825
entry.content:
In some countries, it is now possible for people to buy products made in other countries. To what extend do the benefits of this development outweigh the problems?

It is common for people to purchase imported products such as food and clothes. I think it is a positive change, although it has a damaging effect on the environment.

Importing products is beneficial to consumers because it can reduce the cost of living for many of them. Countries exporting these products have knowledge and technology to control the cost of production, which leads to lower prices. In addition, fierce competition forces local producers to cut prices. Consumers can benefit from it because they have more disposable income.

Another benefit is that consumers have more options in shopping. It is difficult for inhabitants to buy some food products and household goods in some areas due to geographic locations and weather conditions. Imported goods allow them to improve the standard of living because they can buy products they need. For example, imported food is likely to alleviate the food shortage caused by extreme weather in some regions.

On the other hand, the downside of importing products is that it may be harmful to the environment. It is necessary for importers to transport their products a long distance. Transportation can cause pollution since both airplanes and vehicles create emissions.

In conclusion, I believe that importing products has a beneficial effect on consumers although it can cause damage to the environment.

entry.title: IELTS-Writing-Answer-0826
entry.content:
In some countries young people are encouraged to work or travel for a year between finishing high school and starting university studies.

Discuss the advantages and disadvantages for young people who decide to do this. (I05T02W02)

It is quite common those days for young people in many countries to have a break from studying after graduating from high school. The trend is not restricted to rich students who have many to travel, but is also evident among poorer students who choose to work and become economically independent for a period of time.

The reasons for this trend may involve the recognition that a young adult who passes directly from school to university is rather restricted in terms of general knowledge and experience of the world. By contrast, those who have spent some time earning a living or traveling to other places, have broader view of life and better personal resources to draw on. They tend to be more independent, which is very important factor in academic study and research, as well as giving them an advantage in terms of coping with the challenges of student life.

However, there are certainly dangers in taking time off at that important age. Young adults may end up never returning to their studies or finding it difficult to readapt to an academic environment. They may think that it is better to continue in a particular job, or to do something completely different from a university course. But overall, I think this is less likely toady, when academic qualifications are essential for getting a reasonable career.

My view is that young people should be encouraged to broaden their horizons. That is the best way for them to get a clear perspective of what they are hoping to do with their lives and why. Students with such a perspective are usually the most effective and motivated ones and taking a year off may be the best way to gain this.

Some people think that a sense of competition in children should be encouraged. Others believe that children who are taught to co-operate rather than compete become more useful adults.

Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.(I05T03W02)

Competitiveness among humans, based largely on selfishness, seems to be more instinctive trait than co-operation, which seems to be mostly learned behaviour. Although both of these traits have evolved to ensure our survival as a species. I believe that our continued survival will depend on our ability to co-operate and this will only result from fostering competitiveness. No form of behaviour can be more useful to humanity than that which ensure our survival.

Prehistoric humans competed for resources such as access to wild animals and this resulted in fighting and killing other humans. This ensured the survival of the fittest in the struggle against the threats of nature. Although intelligence played a part in fighting, physical strength was the predominant factor, reflecting our need to overcome physical challenges to our survival. Today, however, we humans use intelligence to overcome our challenges and ensure our survival but warfare and the killing of other humans continues. With the destructive power of nuclear warfare, our whole species is threatened and it is imperative that we learn to co-operate more with each other and eliminate war. Towards this aim, selfishness and unbridled competition must be discouraged in children because the inevitable result will be war over dwindling natural resources.

Of course, not all competition is negative. Fair competition in business results in greater efficiency, intellectual competition ensures the best intellectual output from humans, and sports, especially team sports, are a useful substitute for war between groups of humans. However, in reality, all humanity is now interdependent and, for the benefit of all, it is vital that we accentuate sharing and co-operation.

entry.title: IELTS_Writing_Model_Essay_01
entry.content:
Instead of asking the government to bear the cost of higher education, students should pay their tuition fees themselves. Do you agree or disagree with this statement?

Model Essay

Some people consider it necessary for the government to subsidies all universities to ensure that all eligible students can attend college free of charge. I do not agree with this idea, although students of low socio-economic status can be exempt(å…é™¤) from tuition fees.

Tuition fees can raise studentâ€™s engagement as the staggering(æƒŠäººçš„) financial cost may pressure them to take this opportunity more seriously. They may finance their education with their own saving or the money borrowed from relatives(äº²æˆš), so they would do the utmost(æœ€å¤§åŠªåŠ›) to complete all courses and obtain a degree as soon as possible. If they fail to pass any exam or gain a passing grade for any assignment, they might have to delay the plan to enter the workforce. This may incur(æ‹›è‡´) a higher cost than they can afford. This sense of urgency would disappear if they had free access to education. Absenteeism(æ—·è¯¾) and passing rates of each subject would increase markedly, making it difficult for a tertiary institution(å¤§ä¸“é™¢æ ¡) to operate effectively.

Another reason for charging tuition is that it can lighten the burden on the government and increase financial resources available for other levels of education. University students have reached adulthood when they are capable of earning a living. If they place value on academic qualifications, they can set aside(æç½®,é¢„ç•™) part of their income to finance their degree courses. By comparison, primary and secondary education deserve more of government expenditure as students are still deemed as minors(è¢«è§†ä¸ºæœªæˆå¹´äºº), who are not legally permitted to work as paid employees. Postgraduate programmers are also in need of financial support form the state, without which universities would lose the battle with the private sector for talented researchers.

On the other side, it may be reasonable to make some exceptions and provide less well-off(å°åº·,é˜”ç»°çš„) students with free education. Free tuitions can encourage these young students to attend college and increase knowledge so they are able to find employment in this knowledge-based economy. Without a tertiary-level qualification(å¤§ä¸“å­¦å†), they might end up working in low-paid, manual work, while their counterparts from well-off backgrounds dominate the high-paying, professional jobs, such as medicine and law, which require advanced qualifications. This can perpetuate(æ°¸å­˜) the income disparity problem of a economy.

To sum up, students from disadvantages backgrounds can be exempt from tuition fees, while it is not acceptable to abolish tuition fees for everyone.

It is better for students to live away from home while studying at university than to live with parents. To what extend do you agree or disagree?

Model Essay

Many college students choose to move out of their parental home and live in university accommodation or share flats with friends. In my opinion, they can benefit from this option, although their bonding with family may suffer.

One benefit of leaving home is that young people can develop independence. Without the support and guidance of parents, they should make decisions independently on a wide range of issues, such as the length of the lease(ç§Ÿçº¦æœŸé™), choosing a flatmate(å®¤å‹) and refurnishing the flat they rent if necessary. Apart from the decision-making ability, they also develop a variety of skills, including managing the monthly budget and keeping a house, which can prepare them for challenges in their working lives. For example, tidying up the bedroom every day is fundamentally an organizational skill, which is essential when they expect to keep office documents in an orderly fashion and complete routine tasks efficiently when they enter the workforce.

Living separately from parents also mean that young people can enjoy greater freedom in social life and enhance interpersonal skills. They do not need to go home every day and report to parents about their daily activities, so they have more free time to make new friends , such as joining some clubs. going to the gym, attending parities and even taking up a part-time job. They can sharpen their social skills by conversing with people from all walks of life in different settings. They can build a network of contacts, which is of value to their career in the future as they have more personal resource to draw upon.

On the other hand, some young people should be aware that they may have to combat the sense of loneliness when living apart from family. They may not be able to eat meals with parents every day to enjoy the bonding with family and solicit advice when they experience difficulties in their education. In order to maintain a sense of independence, some students may choose to hide their feelings even when they cannot cope with challenges alone. They will stay aloof from parents after graduation, as they do not see the value in maintaining close contact with family.

To sum up, I agree with the idea of living independently when young people start university, despite the possible impact on family life.

entry.content:
æœ¬æ–‡ç³»æµ™å¤§å¶èˆªå®è§‚ç»æµå­¦è¯¾ç¨‹ç³»åˆ—ç¬”è®°ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰çš„ç¬¬äºŒå°èŠ‚ï¼Œä¸»è¦è®²è§£ IS-LM æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

å•†å“å¸‚åœºçš„å‡è¡¡ä¸ISæ›²çº¿

IS æ›²çº¿çš„æ¨å¯¼

a å’Œ $\alpha$ æ˜¯è‡ªå‘æ€§ï¼Œæ¨¡å‹ä¸­ç»™å®šçš„ã€‚

ä¾‹é¢˜1ï¼šå·²çŸ¥æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•° $C = 200+0.8Y$ï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„å‡½æ•°$I = 300-5r$ï¼›æ±‚ IS æ›²çº¿çš„æ–¹ç¨‹ã€‚

è§£:$A = (a+\alpha)/\beta=(200 + 300)/ 5 = 100$

$B = (1-b)/\beta=(1 - 0.8)/ 5 = 0.04$

IS æ›²çº¿çš„æ–¹ç¨‹ä¸ºï¼š$r = 100 - 0.04Y$

ISæ›²çº¿çš„ç»æµå«ä¹‰

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰IS æ›²çº¿æ˜¯ä¸€æ¡æè¿°å•†å“å¸‚åœºè¾¾åˆ°å®è§‚å‡è¡¡å³ $I = S$ æ—¶ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºä¸åˆ©ç‡ä¹‹é—´å…³ç³»çš„æ›²çº¿ã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰åœ¨å•†å“å¸‚åœºä¸Šï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºä¸åˆ©ç‡ä¹‹é—´å­˜åœ¨ç€åå‘å˜åŒ–çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œå³åˆ©ç‡æé«˜æ—¶æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³è¶‹äºå‡å°‘ï¼Œåˆ©ç‡é™ä½æ—¶æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³è¶‹äºå¢åŠ ã€‚

ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰å¤„äº IS æ›²çº¿ä¸Šçš„ä»»ä½•ç‚¹ä½éƒ½è¡¨ç¤º $I = S $ï¼Œå³å•†å“å¸‚åœºå®ç°äº†å®è§‚å‡è¡¡ã€‚åä¹‹ï¼Œåç¦» IS æ›²çº¿çš„ä»»ä½•ç‚¹ä½éƒ½è¡¨ç¤º $I \neq S$ ï¼Œå³å•†å“å¸‚åœºæ²¡æœ‰å®ç°å®è§‚å‡è¡¡ã€‚

å¦‚æœæŸä¸€ç‚¹ä½å¤„äº IS æ›²çº¿çš„å³è¾¹ï¼ˆAç‚¹ï¼‰ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤º $I < S$ ï¼Œå³ç°è¡Œçš„åˆ©ç‡æ°´å¹³è¿‡é«˜ï¼Œä»è€Œå¯¼è‡´æŠ•èµ„è§„æ¨¡å°äºå‚¨è“„è§„æ¨¡ã€‚

å¦‚æœæŸä¸€ç‚¹ä½å¤„äº IS æ›²çº¿çš„å·¦è¾¹ï¼ˆBç‚¹ï¼‰ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤º $I > S$ ï¼Œå³ç°è¡Œçš„åˆ©ç‡æ°´å¹³è¿‡ä½ï¼Œä»è€Œå¯¼è‡´æŠ•èµ„è§„æ¨¡å¤§äºå‚¨è“„è§„æ¨¡ã€‚

ISæ›²çº¿çš„æ°´å¹³ç§»åŠ¨

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰å¦‚æœåˆ©ç‡æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–ï¼Œç”±å¤–ç”Ÿç»æµå˜é‡å†²å‡»å¯¼è‡´æ€»äº§å‡ºå¢åŠ ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è§†ä½œåŸæœ‰çš„ IS æ›²çº¿åœ¨æ°´å¹³æ–¹å‘å³ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰å¦‚æœåˆ©ç‡æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–ï¼Œç”±å¤–ç”Ÿç»æµå˜é‡å†²å‡»å¯¼è‡´æ€»äº§å‡ºå‡å°‘ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è§†ä½œåŸæœ‰çš„ IS æ›²çº¿åœ¨æ°´å¹³æ–¹å‘å·¦ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

ISæ›²çº¿çš„ç§»åŠ¨æ—‹è½¬

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰IS æ›²çº¿æ–œç‡çš„ç»æµæ„ä¹‰ï¼šæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„æ•æ„Ÿç¨‹åº¦ã€‚æ–œç‡è¶Šå¤§ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„ååº”è¶Šè¿Ÿé’ã€‚åä¹‹ï¼Œæ–œç‡è¶Šå°ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„ååº”è¶Šæ•æ„Ÿã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰å†³å®š IS æ›²çº¿æ–œç‡çš„å› ç´ ï¼š$Y$ çš„ç³»æ•°$(1-b)/\beta$ï¼Œå¦‚æœ $\beta$ ä¸å˜ï¼Œè¾¹é™…æ¶ˆè´¹å€¾å‘ $b$ ä¸ IS æ›²çº¿çš„æ–œç‡æˆåæ¯”ã€‚å¦‚ $b$ ä¸å˜ï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„ç³»æ•° $\beta$ ä¸ IS æ›²çº¿çš„æ–œç‡æˆåæ¯”ã€‚

ï¼ˆä¸ºäº†ç®€åŒ–ï¼Œå‡å®šä»·æ ¼æ€»æ°´å¹³ä¸º 1 ï¼Œå³ $M=m$ ï¼‰

ä¾‹é¢˜2ï¼šå·²çŸ¥è´§å¸ä¾›åº”é‡ $M = 300$ï¼Œè´§å¸éœ€æ±‚é‡ $L = 0.2Y - 5r$ï¼›æ±‚ LM æ›²çº¿çš„æ–¹ç¨‹ã€‚
è§£ï¼š$E = - m/h = - 300 / 5 = - 60 F = k/h = 0.2 / 5 = 0.04$

LM æ›²çº¿çš„æ–¹ç¨‹ä¸ºï¼š$r = - 60 + 0.04Y$ ã€‚

LM æ›²çº¿çš„ç»æµå«ä¹‰

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰LM æ›²çº¿æ˜¯ä¸€æ¡æè¿°è´§å¸å¸‚åœºè¾¾åˆ°å®è§‚å‡è¡¡å³ $L = M$ æ—¶ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºä¸åˆ©ç‡ä¹‹é—´å…³ç³»çš„æ›²çº¿ã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰åœ¨è´§å¸å¸‚åœºä¸Šï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºä¸åˆ©ç‡ä¹‹é—´å­˜åœ¨ç€æ­£å‘å˜åŒ–çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œå³åˆ©ç‡æé«˜æ—¶æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³è¶‹äºå¢åŠ ï¼Œåˆ©ç‡é™ä½æ—¶æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³è¶‹äºå‡å°‘ã€‚

ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰å¤„äº LM æ›²çº¿ä¸Šçš„ä»»ä½•ç‚¹ä½éƒ½è¡¨ç¤º $L = M$ï¼Œå³è´§å¸å¸‚åœºå®ç°äº†å®è§‚å‡è¡¡ã€‚åä¹‹ï¼Œåç¦» LM æ›²çº¿çš„ä»»ä½•ç‚¹ä½éƒ½è¡¨ç¤º $L \neq M$ï¼Œå³è´§å¸å¸‚åœºæ²¡æœ‰å®ç°å®è§‚å‡è¡¡ã€‚å¦‚æœæŸä¸€ç‚¹ä½å¤„äº LM æ›²çº¿çš„å³è¾¹ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤º $L > M$ ï¼Œå³ç°è¡Œçš„åˆ©ç‡æ°´å¹³è¿‡ä½ï¼Œä»è€Œå¯¼è‡´è´§å¸éœ€æ±‚å¤§äºè´§å¸ä¾›åº”ã€‚å¦‚æœæŸä¸€ç‚¹ä½å¤„äº LM æ›²çº¿çš„å·¦è¾¹ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤º $L < M$ ï¼Œå³ç°è¡Œçš„åˆ©ç‡æ°´å¹³è¿‡é«˜ï¼Œ ä»è€Œå¯¼è‡´è´§å¸éœ€æ±‚å°äºè´§å¸ä¾›åº”ã€‚

LMæ›²çº¿çš„æ°´å¹³ç§»åŠ¨

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰å¦‚æœåˆ©ç‡æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–ï¼Œç”±å¤–ç”Ÿç»æµå˜é‡å†²å‡»å¯¼è‡´æ€»äº§å‡ºå¢åŠ ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è§†ä½œåŸæœ‰çš„ LMæ›²çº¿åœ¨æ°´å¹³å‘å³ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰å¦‚æœåˆ©ç‡æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–ï¼Œç”±å¤–ç”Ÿç»æµå˜é‡å†²å‡»å¯¼è‡´æ€»äº§å‡ºå‡å°‘ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è§†ä½œåŸæœ‰çš„LM æ›²çº¿åœ¨æ°´å¹³å‘å·¦ç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

LMæ›²çº¿çš„æ—‹è½¬ç§»åŠ¨

ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰LMæ›²çº¿æ–œç‡çš„ç»æµæ„ä¹‰ï¼šæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„æ•æ„Ÿç¨‹åº¦ã€‚æ–œç‡è¶Šå°ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„ååº”è¶Šæ•æ„Ÿï¼Œåä¹‹ï¼Œæ–œç‡è¶Šå¤§ï¼Œæ€»äº§å‡ºå¯¹åˆ©ç‡å˜åŠ¨çš„ååº”è¶Šè¿Ÿé’ã€‚

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰å†³å®š LM æ›²çº¿æ–œç‡çš„å› ç´ ï¼š$Y$ çš„ç³»æ•° $(k/h)$ï¼Œå¦‚æœ $h$ ä¸å˜ï¼Œ$k$ ä¸ LM æ›²çº¿çš„æ–œç‡æˆæ­£æ¯”ï¼Œå¦‚æœ $k$ ä¸å˜ï¼Œ$h$ ä¸ LM æ›²çº¿çš„æ–œç‡æˆåæ¯”ã€‚

å•†å“å¸‚åœºã€è´§å¸å¸‚åœºçš„åŒæ—¶å‡è¡¡ä¸ IS-LM æ›²çº¿

è¦ä½¿å¾— $I=S$ï¼Œä» I çš„è§’åº¦æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œé™ä½åˆ©ç‡å¯ä»¥åˆºæ¿€æŠ•èµ„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åœ¨ç»æµå¢é•¿æ”¶ç¼©çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæ¶ˆè´¹è€…é¢„æœŸå¾ˆæ‚²è§‚ï¼Œåˆ©ç‡é™çš„å¤ªä½ä¼šé™·å…¥æµåŠ¨æ€§é™·é˜±ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥åœ¨ç»æµè¡°é€€æ—¶ï¼Œæ”¿åºœå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è´¢æ”¿èµ¤å­—è°ƒæ§ï¼Œ$ï¼ˆT-Gï¼‰$ä¹Ÿè¢«ç§°ä¸ºè´¢æ”¿å› å­ã€‚

ä¾‹1:å·²çŸ¥æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•°C = 1000 + 0.8Yï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„I = 600äº¿å…ƒï¼Œæ±‚æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³Yã€‚

ä¾‹2:å‡è®¾ä¸Šè¿°æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•°ä¸­è‡ªå‘æ€§æ¶ˆè´¹aç”±1000äº¿å…ƒå‡å°‘è‡³900äº¿å…ƒï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„Iä»ä¸º600äº¿å…ƒï¼Œæ±‚æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³Yã€‚

è§£:Y = 900 + 600 / 1 - 0.8 = 7500(äº¿å…ƒ)

ä¾‹3:å‡è®¾æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•°ä»ä¸ºC = 1000 + 0.8Yï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„è§„æ¨¡Iç”±600äº¿å…ƒæ‰©å¤§è‡³650äº¿å…ƒï¼Œæ±‚æ€»äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³Yã€‚

å¯¹æ¯”ä¾‹ 2 å’Œä¾‹ 3 çš„ç»“æœï¼Œå‘ç°æ¶ˆè´¹å‡å°‘ 100 äº¿ä¼šä½¿å¾—äº§å‡ºæ°´å¹³å‡å°‘ 500 äº¿ï¼ŒæŠ•èµ„æ‰©å¤§ 50 äº¿ä¼šä½¿æ€»äº§å‡ºæ‰©å¤§ 250 äº¿ã€‚

å®è§‚ç»æµå­¦ä¸­æœ‰ä¹˜æ•°æ•ˆåº”ï¼ŒæŠ•å…¥çŸ³å¤´ä¼šå¼•èµ·ä¸€æ³¢ä¸€æ³¢çš„å˜åŠ¨ã€‚

æ¶ˆè´¹ä¹˜æ•°ä¸æŠ•èµ„ä¹˜æ•°

åœ¨æŠ•èµ„ $I$ ä¸å˜çš„æ¡ä»¶ä¸‹ï¼Œç”±æ¶ˆè´¹å˜åŒ– $\Delta C$ å¼•èµ·çš„äº§å‡ºå˜åŒ– $\Delta Y$ï¼Œæ ¹æ®å¼ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰æ¥æ¨å¯¼:

$\Delta Y = \Delta a \cdot (1/1 â€“ b )Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·(4)$

åœ¨æ¶ˆè´¹ $C$ ä¸å˜çš„æ¡ä»¶ä¸‹ï¼Œç”±æŠ•èµ„å˜åŒ– $\Delta I$ å¼•èµ·çš„äº§å‡ºå˜åŒ– $\Delta Y$ï¼Œæ ¹æ®å¼ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰æ¥æ¨å¯¼ï¼š

$\Delta Y = \Delta I \cdot (1 / 1 â€“ b )Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·Â·(5)$

å¼ï¼ˆ4ï¼‰ä¸­çš„ $1 / 1 - b$ ç§°ä¸ºæ¶ˆè´¹ä¹˜æ•° ï¼Œè®°ä½œ $K_c$ ã€‚

å¼ï¼ˆ5ï¼‰ä¸­çš„ $1 / 1 - b$ ç§°ä¸ºæŠ•èµ„ä¹˜æ•°ï¼Œè®°ä½œ $K_I$ ã€‚

ä¾‹é¢˜ï¼šå‡è®¾è¾¹é™…æ¶ˆè´¹å€¾å‘ $b = 0.8$ ,æ¶ˆè´¹æˆ–æŠ•èµ„æ‰©å¤§ $100$ äº¿å…ƒï¼Œåˆ™ç”±å®ƒå¼•å‘çš„æœ‰æ•ˆéœ€æ±‚çš„å˜åŠ¨ä¸º:

è¿™å’Œé©¬å…‹æ€æ‰€è¯´çš„èµ„æœ¬ä¸»ä¹‰ç»æµæ€»ä¼šå‡ºç°è¿‡å‰©çš„ç»“è®ºä¸€è‡´ï¼Œä½†é©¬å…‹æ€æ˜¯ä»ç”Ÿäº§ç¤¾ä¼šåŒ–å’Œç”Ÿäº§èµ„æ–™ç§äººå æœ‰ä¹‹é—´çš„çŸ›ç›¾ã€‚

æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•°ä¸º:

è€ƒè™‘è´¢æ”¿è½¬ç§»æ”¯ä»˜ $g$ å’Œæ”¿åºœç¨æ”¶ $T$ ï¼Œå±…æ°‘æ¶ˆè´¹çš„å¯æ”¯é…æ”¶å…¥ $Y_d$ ä¸º:

å„é¡¹æ”¿åºœä¹˜æ•°

ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰æ”¿åºœè½¬ç§»æ”¯ä»˜å¯¹æœ‰æ•ˆéœ€æ±‚çš„å½±å“:

ä¸¤ç§ç¨æ”¶å½¢å¼ä¸‹çš„å„é¡¹ä¹˜æ•°

ç¨æ”¶æœ‰å®šé¢ç¨å’Œæ¯”ä¾‹ç¨ä¹‹åˆ†ï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬è€ƒå¯Ÿçš„æ˜¯ä¸¤ç§å½¢å¼çš„ç¨æ”¶ï¼Œåˆ™ç¨æ”¶ $Tâ€™= T + tY$ ï¼Œå¼ä¸­ $T$ ä¸ºå›ºå®šç¨ï¼Œ$t$ ä¸ºæ¯”ä¾‹ç¨ç‡ã€‚åœ¨è¿™ä¸€æƒ…å†µä¸‹å±…æ°‘çš„å¯æ”¯é…æ”¶å…¥ä¸ºï¼š

ç›¸åº”çš„æ¶ˆè´¹å‡½æ•°ä¸ºï¼š

å°†å¼ï¼ˆä»£å…¥ $Y=C+I+G$ ï¼Œæœ‰ï¼š

ç”±å¼ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰æ¨å¯¼è€Œæ¥çš„å„é¡¹ä¹˜æ•°åˆ™å°†æ”¹å†™ä¸ºï¼š
$K_C=K_I=K_G=1/(1-b+bt)$
$K_g= b/(1-b+bt)$

entry.title: Notes-of-mixtape
entry.content:
This book is an introduction to research designs that can recover causal effects. But just as importantly, it provides you with hands-on practice to implement these designs. Implementing these designs means writing code in some type of software. I have chosen to illustrate these designs using two popular software languages: Stata (most commonly used by economists) and R (most commonly used by everyone else).

Introduction

Correlation not equals to causality

two types of data:

  • experimental data(usually collected through surveys, or by-product of some other business activity)
  • non-experimental data (observational data)

To put it as bluntly as I can, economic theory says choices are endogenous, and therefore since they are, the correlations between those choices and outcomes in the aggregate will rarely, if ever, represent a causal effect.

Emprical analysis: using data to test a theory or to estimate a relationship between variables.

Probability and Regression Review

Directed Acyclic Graphs

DAGs are a graphical tool which provide a way to visually represent and better understand the key concepts of exposure, outcome, causation, confounding, and bias (Williams et al., 2018).

DAG Notation

direct

mediated by a third variable

backdoor criterion

collider bias

Potential Outcomes Causal Model

å¦‚ä½•è·å–ï¼Ÿ

åœ¨ data é¡µé¢ï¼ˆå¦‚ä¸Šå›¾ï¼‰å¯ä»¥å¡«å…¥éœ€è¦ä¸‹è½½çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå³å¯è·å–æˆ–è€…ä¸‹è½½ CSV æ ¼å¼çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚

ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è°ƒç”¨ API æ‰¹é‡è·å–æ•°æ®API è¯´æ˜æ–‡æ¡£ï¼Œæ„é€ è¯·æ±‚æ‰€éœ€ä¸»è¦å‚æ•°å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

Stata è·å–

å‘½ä»¤ä»‹ç»

ä½¿ç”¨ API è¯·æ±‚æ•°æ®çš„å‘½ä»¤è¯­æ³•å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š


å„é€‰é¡¹å«ä¹‰å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼ˆæ–‡æ¡£å†™çš„æ¯”è¾ƒæ¸…æ™°ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±ç›´æ¥æ¬è¿å¸®åŠ©æ–‡æ¡£äº†ï¼‰ï¼š

  • hs(string) sets the px parameter, the product classification scheme. Can be HS,H0, H1, H2,H4,H5, ST, S1, S2, S3, S4, BEC or EB02. See the webpage or Stata for valid parameters.
  • class(string) sets the cc parameter, the detailed product classification code. string can be: TOTAL (Total trade between reporter and partner, no detail breakdown), AG1, AG2, AG3, AG4, AG5, AG6 and ALL (all codes).AG1 - AG6 are detailed codes at a specific digit level. For instance AG6 in HS gives all of the 6-digit codes, which are the most detailed codes that are internationally comparable. Not all classifications have all digit levels available. See the classification specific codes for more information.
  • reportercountry(string) sets the r parameter, the reporter country. See list of valid reporters in web or in Stata.
  • partnercountry(string) sets the p parameter, the partner country. See list of valid partners web or in Stata
  • type(string) sets the type parameter, the trade data type. Values can be C for commodities and S for services.
  • freq(string) sets the freq parameter, the frequency. Valid values are A for annual and M for monthly.
  • traderegime(string) sets the rg parameter, the trade regime. Valid values are all for imports and exports, 1 for imports and 2 for exports. See valid parameters in web or Stata.
  • years(string) sets the ps parameter, the time period. Format can be YYYY, YYYYMM, now or recent.
  • imts(string) data fields/columns based on IMTS Concepts & Definitions. Can be 2010 for data complying with IMTS 2010 or orig for earlier versions. Is optional.
  • maxdata(string) sets the max parameter, maximum number of records to be returned.

Python-tesseract is an optical character recognition (OCR) tool for python. That is, it will recognize and â€œreadâ€ the text embedded in images. Python-tesseract is a wrapper for Googleâ€™s Tesseract-OCR Engine. It is also useful as a stand-alone invocation script to tesseract, as it can read all image types supported by the Pillow and Leptonica imaging libraries, including jpeg, png, gif, bmp, tiff, and others. Additionally, if used as a script, Python-tesseract will print the recognized text instead of writing it to a file.(from pytesseract project description)
